Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Expectation2: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation2: The ambulance driver is conducting a routine check of the first-aid kit to ensure all supplies are present and not expired.
Story: I was halfway through checking the first-aid kit in the back of the ambulance, ticking off bandages and vials, when my phone buzzed. It was a message from Mia: “Can you talk? I had a terrible day.” I glanced at the clock—my shift had just started, and protocol demanded that I finish the supply check before we could respond to any calls. But I could picture her, sitting on the couch, eyes red, replaying the harsh words from her boss. She needed me to listen, to reassure her, to be present. Yet, the weight of my uniform pressed on me, reminding me that if I missed a missing item, it could cost someone their life later. My mind raced between the sterile order of the ambulance and the raw emotion in Mia’s text. I wanted to drop everything and call her, but I also knew the responsibility I carried here. The expectations from both sides pulled at me, and I stood frozen, phone in one hand, checklist in the other, heart torn between duty and love.
